headline: Editor-in-chief of Science encourages researchers to communicate | Virginia Tech News | Virginia Tech
context: Holden Thorp visited Virginia Tech’s Blacksburg and Roanoke campuses as part of the Research Integrity and Consultation Program’s Research Integrity and Scholarly Excellence Lecture Series.

annotations.reason: This is a reading time estimate and does not contribute to the article's core story.

annotations.paragraph: The editor-in-chief of a leading international science journal presented a challenge to the Virginia Tech research community.
annotations.reason: This introduces the main event and sets the stage for the article's focus.

annotations.paragraph: “What can we do to be different from the intuitions that are losing trust,” said Holden Thorp, editor-in-chief of Science. “The main thing is to be much more open and conversational than most of the [other societal] institutions that are out there.”
annotations.reason: This quote directly relates to the article's theme of communication and trust in science.

annotations.paragraph: A part of the Research Integrity and Consultation Program’s Research Integrity and Scholarly Excellence (RISE) Lecture Series, Thorp visited Virginia Tech’s Blacksburg campus on April 22 to speak about the challenges of scientific research and communication in the current landscape. He shared examples of missteps researchers and publications have made in the past and some best practices for engaging with both the public and media.
annotations.reason: This provides context about the event and Thorp's focus on communication challenges.

annotations.paragraph: Thorp said while the collective science community has lost some public trust compared with past years, recent survey data shows it to be viewed as quite trustworthy compared to other institutions in society.
annotations.reason: This offers relevant commentary on the current state of trust in the science community.

annotations.paragraph: “As of today, 76 percent of U.S. adults have confidence in science to act in the best interest of the public. That’s higher than almost any other institution,” said Thorp, citing data from a 2024 Pew Research Center study.
annotations.reason: Provides relevant data supporting the public's confidence in science, which is central to the article's theme.

annotations.paragraph: Among other groups, the percentage was higher than that for religious leaders at 55 percent, public school principals at 72 percent, and elected officials at 33 percent.
annotations.reason: Offers comparative context to highlight the public's confidence in science.

annotations.paragraph: Thorp shared several thoughts on actions and attitudes the scientific community should embrace to increase public trust. They include:
annotations.reason: Introduces Thorp's suggestions for increasing public trust, relevant to the article's focus.

annotations.paragraph: “We have the privilege of spending taxpayer money to do research and we have obligations to the people who paid that, and that is to be willing to talk to them about the things they are criticizing us for,” Thorp said.
annotations.reason: Direct quote from Thorp emphasizing the responsibility of scientists to communicate with the public.

annotations.paragraph: Iris Jenkins, director of the Research Integrity and Consultation Program, said Thorp’s experience as an insider on matters of both research and publishing ethics made him an ideal fit for the lecture series.
annotations.reason: Provides context on why Thorp was chosen for the lecture series, relevant to the article.

annotations.paragraph: “The theme of our RISE series this year is Navigating 21st Century Challenges to Scientific Research,” Jenkins said. “Dr. Thorp is familiar with the challenges to scientific research and has written about ways to manage them. We knew the Virginia Tech research community would benefit greatly from the opportunity to engage with him and learn from his perspectives.”
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides context about the lecture series and highlights Thorp's relevance to the event.

annotations.paragraph: Past events may be viewed on the RISE Lecture video page.

This includes everything from consultations to its peer-to-peer learning model for training researchers in the responsible conduct of research.

annotations.paragraph: “Our division is here to support research excellence,” Jenkins said. “We want to see researchers succeed and provide the support they need to do so. Whether it is assistance with meeting regulatory requirements or, thinking through complex ethical issues, we are here to help.”
